results.title: Cry-baby = Cry baby
results.creator_credit: John Waters, Rachel Talalay, Universal Pictures and Imagine Entertainment (US)
results.brief_description: Johnny Depp is Wade “Cry-baby” Walker, a cool, tough but sensitive teenage delinquent. His ability to shed a single tear drives the girls wild. Cry-baby and his friends live on the outer edges of “normal society”. Their “badness” attracts the beautiful rich but square Allison and she is drawn into their rockabilly, fast car world. The soundtrack is excellent, and the rock ‘n roll era of the 1950’s is vividly recreated. Johnny Depp is appealing as Cry-baby and is well supported by co-stars Amy Locane, Susan Tyrell, Iggy Pop, Ricky Lake, Traci Lords and Polly Bergen. John Waters style is firmly stamped on this film as he recreates a nostalgia for an era.

results.title: Crumb
results.creator_credit: Terry Zwigoff, Lynn O'Donnell and Superior Pictures
results.brief_description: This surreal documentary about animator and director Robert Crumb was partly financed by David Lynch. Crumb was an underground counter-cultural comic artist who confronted taboos by examining sex, drugs and violence in his animated films and comics, most famously in “Fritz the Cat.” Crumb has continued to work in his anarchic manner but the collapse of the counterculture led to his increasing alienation and separation from the commercial art world. This documentary is confronting as an intimate study of an eccentric life, but it also reveals much about the nexus between imagination and personality, between family history and present relationships. Sometimes almost brutally naked, “Crumb” is an innovative study of a uniquely talented animator and comic. Winner of the Grand Jury Prize at the Sundance Film Festival.

results.title: Cringe and they'll come running: an environmental study
results.creator_credit: Bill Meyer, Experimental Film and Television Fund and Skin and Hair Flick Co
results.brief_description: In this film, a broad spectrum of well-known contemporary Melbourne artists comment on their own work, their relationships with other artists, and the nature of Australian art. Focuses on the relationship between art and the environment, contrasting urban with the rural landscape, and realism with modernism and conceptualism. Shows the art of sculpture blending into the city landscape and includes many visual images of Melbourne city and suburbs such as the newly opened Tullamarine Airport, National Gallery of Victoria, the freeways and overpasses and high-rise development constructed during the sixties, local art galleries and museums as well as outer Melbourne bush and bayside scenes. Artists include: Bruce Pollard, John Brack, Kevin Gronow, Alun Leach-Jones, Clifford Last, Ruth McNicoll, Lenton Parr, Jan Senbergs, Guy Stuart, Trevor Kretchmar, Andrew Sibley, Dennis Spiteri, Fred Williams and others. Contains some B&W footage.

results.title: Cruising
results.creator_credit: William Friedkin, Jerry Weintraub and Lorimar Film Entertainment
results.brief_description: On its initial release in 1980, “Cruising” was the target of criticism and protest by gay and lesbian activists who saw it as a negative and destructive portrayal of urban gay life. In retrospect, “Cruising” proves to be one of the most fascinating and chilling dramas about sexuality and violence to come out of Hollywood. Al Pacino plays Steve Burns, a heterosexual cop who has to go undercover in New York’s gay S/M subculture to uncover the identity of a serial killer who is murdering gay young men. As Burns becomes increasingly immersed in the highly sexualised world of gay S/M, he finds his own identity, centred on fixed definitions of gender and monogamous fidelity, challenged by the seductive allure of promiscuity, fast sex and drugs. As the film unfolds, his search for the killer becomes confused by the unleashing of his own repressed desires. Director Friedkin is known for his fast-paced and highly kinetic movies such as “The French connection” and “The Exorcist”, “Cruising” is equally taut and frightening. It is also a film which explores graphically the connections between violence, sexuality, homophobia and masculinity. Far from being a destructive portrayal of gay life, “Cruising” refuses neat sociological positive stereotyping and instead offers chilling insights into the aggressive desires of men, whatever their sexuality. Based on the novel by Gerald Walker.

results.title: Cruel intentions
results.creator_credit: Roger Kumble, Neal H. Moritz and Columbia Pictures
results.brief_description: Mercenary manipulator Kathryn, furious at being dumped for the painfully naive Cecile, plots revenge on her ex-boyfriend Court by goading her amoral step-brother Sebastian to seduce her and ruin her reputation. Sebastian is initially reluctant, revealing his interest in a more challenging potential conquest - the headmaster’s daughter Annette, who has vowed in a magazine article to forego sex before marriage. Undeterred, Kathryn proposes a more seductive wager: if Sebastian can successfully seduce Annette before school resumes in the fall, she will give him the one thing he has desperately desired since their parents got married… However, if he fails, then Kathryn gets to keep his most prized possession, a 1956 Jaguar Roadster. With the stakes so high, both of them are determined to win at all costs, leaving a trail of victims in their wake. It is only when their diabolical schemes take a few unexpected turns that they begin to realise the far-reaching consequences of their actions. Cruel Intentions is the fourth film adaptation of Les Liaisons Dangereuses, Choderlos de Laclos’ scandalous 1782 novel that portrayed sexual manipulation as an art form. Stars Sarah Michelle Gellar as Kathryn, Ryan Phillippe as Sebastian, Reese Witherspoon as Annette, and Selma Blair as Cecile.

results.title: Crescent moon = Yueyaer  = 月牙儿
results.creator_credit: An Xiao Hua, Ting Mei, Zhanag Fan, Wang Zhi An, Huo Zhuang, Li Dong De, Xing Dan, Xu Xiaoxing and Beijing Film Studio
results.brief_description:
Based on a short story written in the 1930s by Lao She, ‘Crescent Moon’ portrays the inexorable injustice exerted by an unfair economic system, through the reminiscences of a young girl gradually forced into prostitution by poverty. Yuerong’s father dies when she is only a little girl; her mother remarries a kind patron, but he dies too. Penury pushes her mother into prostitution, for which Yuerong cannot forgive her. She leaves home and lives at school, but after graduation is unable to find work. She lets a man take care of her for a while, but then discovers he is married. Later she becomes a waitress, but loses the job when she refuses to sleep with the customers. In the end she has no choice but to follow in her mother’s footsteps.

Credits: Directors, Huo Zhuang, Xu Xiaoxing, Xing Dan ; writers, Huo Zhuang, Zhang Fan, Wang Zhi’an ; photography, Sun Cheng, Meng Fanjun ; music, Liv Zhuang ; editing, Zhon Tingmei, An Xiaohua.
Cast: Song Dandan, Siqin Gaowa.

results.title: Cree way
results.creator_credit: Tony Ianzelo, Mark Zannis and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: John Murdock, principal of the Indian Affairs at Rupert House, James Bay, and his wife Gerti, have initiated a curriculum development project using local people and resources. The teaching materials are drawn from Cree folklore, are mainly in Cree, and make use of old photographs, artifacts and books that are written and printed in the community. The school year is organised so that pupils have time to go hunting and fishing with their families. This innovative approach makes local control of education a reality in native communities.
